covered: PUT - Valid Request: Successful 204 updates with minimal and full payloads (TC01, TC02).
PUT - Partial Update: Supported and verified that only provided fields change (TC19, TC15).
Query Parameter behavior: treatNullAsReset true resets fields; false/omitted leaves fields unchanged (TC03, TC04).
Path parameter validation: Invalid UUID format -> 400 (TC06).
Invalid body validation: Bad schema/values -> 400 (TC07, TC21).
Non-existing resource handling: Update non-existent account -> error response (TC08).
Extra input tolerance: Extra body fields and query params ignored without failing update (TC10, TC22).
Performance/robustness: Large payloads and latency/timeout conditions covered (TC13, TC14).
Concurrency: Concurrent updates handled gracefully; final state consistent (TC17).
Security: Injection attempts rejected/sanitized; not persisted (TC18).
Boundary values: Min/Max allowed field values handled (TC20).
Integration effect: Downstream/dependent service reflects update (TC16).
gaps: Status code for non-existent account is specified as 400 in tests; verify whether API should return 404 Not Found (tests assume 400).
Content negotiation/headers: No checks for response headers (e.g., Content-Type on error responses, absence of body on 204).
Unsupported media type: No scenario for wrong Content-Type (e.g., text/plain) -> 415.
Query param validation: No test for invalid treatNullAsReset value (e.g., treatNullAsReset=foo) -> 400.
Idempotency: No test that repeating the same PUT request is idempotent and yields consistent results.
Audit metadata: No verification that X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment are persisted/audited when provided.
Concurrency error semantics: No expectation for conflict/precondition failure codes (e.g., 409) or ETag/If-Match handling if optimistic locking is required.
Authorization vs authentication: 403 Forbidden (authorized user lacking permission) not covered.
Rate limiting/throttling: No scenario for too many requests leading to 429 if applicable.
recommendations: Clarify expected status for non-existent account (400 vs 404) and add/adjust scenario accordingly.
Add scenarios to validate response headers: ensure 204 has no body; error responses include application/json Content-Type and useful error payload.
Add a scenario for unsupported media type: sending non-JSON body -> 415.
Add a negative test for treatNullAsReset with non-boolean value -> 400.
Add an idempotency test: send the same valid PUT twice and confirm state and responses are consistent.
Extend tests to assert audit persistence of X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment (e.g., via audit endpoints or logs).
If optimistic concurrency is supported, add ETag/If-Match precondition tests and 409 Conflict expectations; otherwise, document that last-write-wins is intended.
Add a 403 Forbidden scenario to distinguish authentication (401) from authorization (403).
If the platform enforces rate limits, add a 429 Too Many Requests scenario with appropriate headers (Retry-After).
